facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 283 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No283 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 10, 1968 of Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 453 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 10, 1968 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 453 of 1966.

facts.text: Appellants are accused Nos. 2 to 5, tried along with first accused Sia Devi wife of 5th accused.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, who are accused Nos. 2 to 5, along with the first accused Sia Devi  wife of 5th accused  were tried by the learned First Assistant Sessions Judge, Biharsharif,

facts.text: Tried by First Assistant Sessions Judge, Biharsharif for offence under Section 363 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: were tried by the learned First Assistant Sessions Judge, Biharsharif, for an offence under Section 363 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Kanta Kumari is orphan minor niece of complainant P.W.1 Parmeshwar Pandey, under his guardianship since death of her parents.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution was as follows One Kanta Kumari, an orphan minor, and niece of the company- plainant  P. W. 1  Parmeshwar Pandey was under the lawful guardianship and protection of the latter and residing with him since the death of her parents.

facts.text: On February 14, 1965 at about 8 P.M., two accused came to house of complainant and called Kanta Kumari.

anchor.surface_text: At about 8 P. M. on February to the house of the companyplainant and called Kanta KumaKanta Kumari responded to the call by companying out.

facts.text: Kanta Kumari went out with two accused saying she was going for singing marriage songs, returned by midnight.

anchor.surface_text: When she wasquestioned by her uncle as to where she was going out with the two, accused, Kanta Kumari replied that she was going out for singing marriage songs. Kanta Kumari went away with the two accused and returned home by about mid- night.

facts.text: On morning of February 15, 1965, complainant found Kanta Kumari missing.

anchor.surface_text: In the morning of February 15, 1965, the companyplainant found that Kanta Kumari was missing from his house.

facts.text: Kanta Kumari seen at 3 A.M. on February 15, 1965 going with all five accused for Ganga Ashnan.

anchor.surface_text: On a search made by him, he came to know that Kanta Kumari was seen early that morning at about 3 A. M. going in the companypany of all the five accused persons for Ganga Ashnan.

facts.text: On evening of February 17, 1965, complainant met first and fifth accused, informed by fifth that accused 2 and 3 took Kanta Kumari.

anchor.surface_text: But on the evening of February 17, 1965, when he met the first and the fifth accused in the village, he was informed by the fifth accused that his paternal companysins, accused Nos. 2 and 3, had taken away Kanta Kumari with them.

facts.text: On February 18, 1965, Parmeshwar Pandey filed complaint alleging kidnapping of minor Kanta Kumari by five accused.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving this information, Parmeshwar Pandey lost all hope of his niece Kanta Kumari companying back and on February 18, 1965 he filed a companyplaint before the police alleging that his niece Kanta Kumari, a minor, has been kidnaped from his lawful guardianship by the five accused.

facts.text: All five accused charged under Section 363 IPC for kidnapping minor Kanta Kumari on February 15, 1965 from guardianship of uncle.

anchor.surface_text: All the five accused were charged under Section 363 1. P. C. for kidnaping the minor girl Kanta Kumari on February 15, 1965 from the lawful guardianship of her uncle Parmeshwar Pandey without his companysent.

facts.text: Accused pleaded not guilty, falsely implicated due to enmity; denied niece exists, denied kidnapping, claimed Kanta Kumari major 18 years.

anchor.surface_text: All the accused pleaded number guilty before the trial companyrt and stated that they were falsely implicated by Parmeshwar Pandey on account of long standing enmity. In particular they pleaded  a  that Parmeshwar Pandey had numberniece called Kanta Kumari  b  they have number kidnaped Kanta Kumari and  c  in any case Kanta Kumari was number a minor as alleged but was a major about 18 years of age.

facts.text: Trial court judgment dated August 31, 1966: rejected accused pleas, held Kanta Kumari 9-10 years old, convicted accused 2-5 under S.363 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Assistant Sessions Judge by his judgment and order dated August 31, 1966 substantially rejected all the pleas of the accused. The learned Judge held that the companyplainant Parmeshwar Pandey, who had given evidence as P. I had a niece by name Kanta Kumari, who was living with him under his guardianship as she had lost her parents. Though Kanta Kumari ,Was number traced and as such she was number before the companyrt, the learned Judge held that Kanta Kumari at the time of the occurrence must have been only 9 or 10 years old.

facts.text: Trial court sentenced appellants to RI 5 years, fine Rs.500, default RI 6 months; acquitted accused No.1 Sia Devi.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge further held that accused Nos. 2 to 5  appellants herein  have kidnaped Kanta Kumari, a minor girl, on February 15, 1965 from the lawful guardianship of her uncle Parmeshwar Pandey without his companysent and as such they were guilty of the offence under Section 363 1. P. C. Accordingly he companyvicted appellants of the said offence and sentenced them to undergo rigorous imprisonment for five years.

facts.text: Appellants filed Criminal Appeal No.453 of 1966 in Patna High Court on September 8, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed Criminal Appeal No. 453 of 1966 in the Patna High Court on September 8, 1966 challenging the various findings recorded by the learned Assistant Sessions judje

facts.text: Patna High Court admitted appeal on September 9, 1966, ordered hearing, issue notice, appellants on bail, stay realization of fine.

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1966 the High Court admitted the appeal and passed the following order 9.9.66 This appeal will be heard. Issue numberice. Pending the hearing of this appeal the appellants will companytinue on bail to the satisfaction of the District Magistrate. The realisation of fine also will remain stayed during the pendency of this appeal.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed appeal on May 10, 1968 for no appearance, found no merit on perusal of judgment under appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was posted for hearing on May 10, 1968. On that date neither the appellants number their companynsel seems to have appeared and the Court dismissed the appeal and passed the fol- lowing order and judgment. 10-5-68. No one appears to press this appeal. On perusal of the judgment under appeal, I find numbermerit in the case.

facts.text: Appellants filed Criminal Miscellaneous Application No.556 of 1968 for restoration on May 10, 1968, dismissed on July 12, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants on the same day filed Criminal Miscellaneous Application No. 556 of 1968 praying for restoration of the Criminal Appeal which had been dismissed by the Court. After issuing numberice in the said application, the High Court on July 12, 1968 dismissed the application, for restoration on the ground that numbersufficient cause has been shown by the appellants.

facts.text: High Court dismissed application for certificate under Article 134(1)(c) on August 2, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed an application for grant of a certificate under Article 134 1   c of the Constitution to appeal to this Court together with an application to excuse delay in filing the application. The High Court dismissed this application on August 2, 1968.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on December 11, 1968 against High Court order dated May 10, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: This Court, however, on December 11, 1968, granted special leave to appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court dated May 10, 1968.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Patna High Court order dated May 10, 1968 not in conformity with Section 423 CrPC, set aside the order.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion, that in passing the impugned order the High Court has number companysidered the material on record before companying to the companyclusion that there was numbercase for inter- ference. As such the order is number in companyformity with Section 423 of the Code hence it has to be set aside.

facts.text: Trial court held Parmeshwar Pandey had niece Kanta Kumari living under his guardianship.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge held that the companyplainant Parmeshwar Pandey, who had given evidence as P. I had a niece by name Kanta Kumari, who was living with him under his guardianship as she had lost her parents.

facts.text: Kanta Kumari not traced, not produced in court.

anchor.surface_text: Though Kanta Kumari ,Was number traced and as such she was number before the companyrt,

facts.text: Accused pleaded long standing enmity with Parmeshwar Pandey.

anchor.surface_text: stated that they were falsely implicated by Parmeshwar Pandey on account of long standing enmity.
were tried by the learned First Assistant Sessions Judge, Biharsharif, for an offence under Section 363 of the Indian Penal Code.

The learned Judge further held that accused Nos. 2 to 5  appellants herein  have kidnaped Kanta Kumari, a minor girl, on February 15, 1965 from the lawful guardianship of her uncle Parmeshwar Pandey without his companysent and as such they were guilty of the offence under Section 363 1. P. C.
are in companyformity with Section 423 of the Code of Criminal Procedure,  hereinafter to be referred as the Code .

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed Criminal Appeal No. 453 of 1966 in the Patna High Court on September 8, 1966 challenging the various findings recorded by the learned Assistant Sessions judge and contending that those findings were not supported by the evidence adduced.

holdings.text: The judgment and order of the Patna High Court dated May 10, 1968, dismissing the Criminal Appeal No. 453 of 1966, are not in conformity with Section 423 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion, that in passing the impugned order the High Court has number companysidered the material on record before companying to the companyclusion that there was numbercase for inter- ference. As such the order is number in companyformity with Section 423 of the Code hence it has to be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court only perused the judgment under appeal and found no merit, without sending for and perusing the full record of the case as mandatorily required by S.423 even in absence of parties.

holdings.text: Under Section 423 CrPC, the Appellate Court must send for the record of the case if not already in court and peruse it before disposing of the appeal, irrespective of appearance of parties.

anchor.surface_text: Section 423 Powers of Appellate Court in disposing of appeal The Appellate Court shall then send for the record of the case, if such record is number already in Court. After perusing such record, and hearing the appellant or his pleader, if he appears, and the Public Prosecutor, if he appears,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of S.423 makes perusal of record obligatory as condition precedent after stages of S.421 and S.422; enables adjudication on merits.

holdings.text: Mere perusal of the judgment under appeal, without perusing the record, does not satisfy the requirements of Section 423 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: On perusal of the judgment under appeal, I find numbermerit in the case. ... We are of the opinion, that in passing the impugned order the High Court has number companysidered the material on record before companying to the companyclusion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record includes evidence and materials beyond judgment; indicated by contrast with S.421 where only petition and judgment copy suffice for summary dismissal.

holdings.text: Once an appeal is admitted under S.421 and notice issued under S.422, the Appellate Court must proceed under S.423 and peruse the record before disposal.

anchor.surface_text: Under Section 421 the Appellate Court is bound to peruse the appeal petition and the copy of the judgment or order appealed against. If the Appellate Court, on perusal of the same, considers that there was no sufficient ground for interfering

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of ss.421-423: summary stage passed after admission and notice; S.423 mandatory for merits disposal.

holdings.text: A criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for default of appearance; the Appellate Court must consider it on merits after perusing the record.

anchor.surface_text: A reading of Section 423 makes it clear that a criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for default of appearance of the appellants or their counsel. The court has either to adjourn the hearing of the appeal

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.423 empowers disposal on merits post-perusal, hearing if present but not requiring presence; protects appellant rights.

holdings.text: The appellate order must indicate that the court has perused the record and applied its mind to the materials.

anchor.surface_text: There must be a clear indication in the judgment or order of the Appellate Court that it has applied its judicial mind to the particular appeal with which it was dealing. Such an indication will be available

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of indication shows non-compliance; routine orders invalid given vast appellate powers under S.423.

holdings.text: The decision in Sankatha Singh v. State of U.P. does not support the validity of the impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: We have gone through the said decision and it does number support the respondent. This Court was number dealing with an order passed by the High Court as an Appellate Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: That case concerned Sessions Judge's restoration power, not High Court S.423 compliance; observations obiter.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed and the impugned order is set aside.

State of Maharashtra.  3  We have referred to the above decisions to show that though a sum- mary rejection by an Appellate Court under Section 421 may number  1  1935 S.C.R. 809. P.  1  and urged that a similar order has been sustained by this Court. We have gone through the said decision and it does number support the respondent. This Court was number dealing with an order passed by the High Court as an Appellate Court.

Section 367 CrPC (c12) addresses whether the High Court order qualifies as a judgment based on its required contents, as questioned in i3.
Section 367 CrPC (c12) addresses the issue of its own applicability to High Court judgments raised in i4.

The concept addresses the issue of whether the High Court order is not a judgment due to lacking points for determination, decision, and reasons, as it pertains to S.367 applicability scope under S.424.

The concept UNLISTED_CRPC_S424 on scope of Section 424 CrPC regarding applicability of S.367 to High Court judgments addresses the issue of whether S.367 does not apply to High Court relying on Section 424.

edges.explanation: Issue i3 addresses Section 367 CrPC as it concerns whether the High Court order lacks the required contents (points for determination, decision, reasons) specified in the section.
Resolving whether the order is not a judgment due to lack of contents (i3) requires determining if Section 367 applies to the High Court (i4).
Issue i4 directly addresses Section 367 CrPC by questioning its applicability to High Court judgments relying on Section 424, matching the argument in c12 label.
The issue explicitly relies on Section 424 of the Code for non-applicability of S.367 to High Court, thus requires the concept of S.424 scope.
